text:
Invented stats to retroactively re-select MVPs and Cy Young Awards going back to 1876. At age 7.

MVP: Batting average (as a three-digit number) + runs + RBIs - HRs
Cy Young: Pitcher winning percentage - team winning percentage in other games - ERA (all as three-digit numbers).

text: I didn't follow closely enough. But what little I saw was that the "If true" standard broadly held. The question--which is hard!--is to figure out how much speculation you're willing to do based on that standard, when it's held by one news organization.

text: Oh, you're not wrong. But it's also true that the "If true" question is frequently worth asking, particularly when the underlying journalism comes from sources who have on balance delivered facts.

text: Reminder that the "If True" file of non-verified stories contains some McClatchy stuff as well. (Though maybe it's all been sorted in a way that has escaped my notice.)

text: Look, in real time, you ask yourself a bunch of questions, including "Has this source been reliable, even while I'm sorting this stuff out?" That's basic media literacy, and it's broadly helpful, regardless of where the final thing lands.

text: Kelleher helped deregulate the airline industry through both demonstration and litigation, he opposed the post-9/11 bailouts, and man did he give good quote. “This was another planet, another world….One of the [government’s] fundamental purposes was to throttle competition.”

text: “Our basic thinking [was that] Southwest would democratize the skies,” Kelleher told me in 2010. “Which we did. I mean, a couple of years ago 85 percent of [Americans] had flown at least one commercial flight as opposed to 15 percent in 1966.”

author: MattWelch

text: Though it *is* included in section where you sign up for the screening test. So like, when you hit "submit" on the application, it's all "Yeah but you didn't apply to the section of the school that you're already signed up to test for." And I'm all NO FUCKING SHIT, SHERLOCK.
author: MattWelch

text: In some of the schools, including one we have interest in, each potential discipline requires a separate test, and a separate application. Here's where the shitty web design comes into play--one of those disciplines at our chosen school IS NOT INCLUDED ON THE APPLICATION SITE.
author: MattWelch

text: THOSE schools -- which can be borough-wide or city-wide -- can still do stuff like look at your kids' grades, test scores, attendance, abilities in various disciplines. Some of those require tests! But you still need to put them on your BEEP-BOOP list.
author: MattWelch

text: Those preferences are combined with a lottery number for each child, plus the (brand new!) requirement that 52% of each school in this district be comprised of poor/ESL/special-needs kids, and BEEP BOOP BEEP BOOP here's what you get! Though non-district schools are different....
author: MattWelch

text: Since I'm going to be on hold w/ NYC DoE for at least the next 20 minutes, let me share some of the joys of being the parent of a 5th grader heading to middle school in Brooklyn. Start with this: You are supposed to list TWELVE schools in order of preference. No time-suck there!

text: I was in the region from August 1990 to December 1997. Covered the expansion of NATO both for Prognosis and UPI, including Clinton's visit to Prague in January 1994 unveiling the "Partnership for Peace." Lived in Prague, Bratislava, Budapest.
author: MattWelch

text: There is a "stab-in-the-back" theory about the Bush admin promising orally during German reunification talks to not expand NATO eastward. For many reasons (not least of which including that I covered NATO expansion closely), I consider that total BS. Not a twitter discussion tho
author: MattWelch

text: The U.S. was *not* dictating terms on economic transition, though obviously had some opinions, and some pull within World Bank/IMF/EBRD & so forth. Generally the West Europeans focused on econ transition, the Americans on security arrangements.

text: The Soviet Union existed for all but 12 months of H.W.'s presidency, so it's hard to see how he could be blamed for econ/rule-of-law perfidy. Each former commie country came up with its own unique transition formula (or lack thereof). and '92 was still embryonic for that.

text: When I saw President George Bush speak in Prague on Nov. 17, 1990, I was appalled. With the passage of time (and at least *some* of my own arrogance), I now have a different view:

text:
Ka-BOOM!
--
Reason: But should the government…

Heston: That's what I'm stepping up to. The government not only has the right but the responsibility to take whatever draconian measures are necessary. Abraham Lincoln suspended the right of habeas corpus in the Civil War... 6/

text:

--
Reason: [Should] the state should proscribe certain forms of nonaggressive behavior—say, alternative lifestyles or smoking [pot?]

Heston: I think narcotics and, for that matter, alcohol, and even tobacco are enormously costly ingredients in our society 5/
author: MattWelch

text:
Then:
--
Reason: The public perception of you politically is that you are…

Heston: A registered Fascist.

Reason: Are you comfortable with the label "conservative"?

Heston: Yes. Particularly in both its general political meaning and the literal meaning, "to save." 4/

text: OK, I'm done with the archives-spelunking on Saudi Arabia. Broader point: They've been playing the U.S. for decades, which is not occasion for a 2018 shrug, but rather a critical self-examination and pants-kick for new approaches from *every* school of American foreign policy.
author: MattWelch

text: While I of course appreciate this more than life itself, I wanna go straight into our shitty-songs-about-Ireland phase. https://travsd.wordpress.com/2016/03/17/lennon-and-mccartney-which-wrote-the-worst-irish-song/ …

text: Also--foreign influence on U.S. elections alert!--Woodward "said Prince Bandar pledged the Saudi's would try to fine-tune oil prices to prime the U.S. economy for the election -- a move they understood would favor Bush's re-election."

text: In "Plan of Attack," Bob Woodward reported that Prince Bandar was alerted to the Iraq War two days before Secretary of State Colin Powell.

text: Anyway, Rich won’t win—9/10 forecasters rate the race a “safe D” (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Senate_elections,_2018 …), and he certainly won’t be making a name for himself in national GOP circles by battling for 2nd place. But it’s interesting to see how the majors sort when facing a real minor threat. 14/X
author: MattWelch
